sentence.text: Patient 1 (a boy) was the first child born to healthy nonconsanguineous Caucasian parents.
After an uneventful pregnancy of 36 + 5 weeks, he was born by vaginal delivery and vacuum extraction.

An Apgar score of 9 was assigned both at 1 and 5 minutes, but in view of increasing respiratory problems and the newborn’s dysmorphic features, he was admitted to the Emma Children’s Hospital/Academic Medical Centre in Amsterdam.
Two earlier pregnancies had resulted in miscarriages.
There was no family history of mental retardation or congenital malformations.
During this pregnancy, ultrasound revealed increased nuchal translucency.
A chorionic villus biopsy was thus performed at 11 weeks’ gestation; results demonstrated a normal male karyotype.

Physical examination of the newborn revealed a cloverleaf-shaped skull, cutis gyrata on the forehead and skull (overlooked or not yet present at first examination, but later recognized on pictures taken at age 11 days), ocular hypertelorism, ocular proptosis, down-slanted palpebral fissures, low nasal bridge, and midface hypoplasia ( Fig 1 A ).
Patient 1 also had bilateral choanal atresia, a high-arched but intact palate, narrow ear canals, a sacral dimple, hypospadia, and a bifid scrotum.

A computed tomographic scan of the head confirmed a bilateral osseous choanal atresia and a craniosynostosis with closure of all sutures except for a proximal part of the coronal suture, the metopic suture, and the distal part of the lambdoid sutures.

Cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a simplified gyral pattern at the level of the basal nuclei ( Fig 1 B, gyral index 1.6 [7] ), abnormal anatomy of the hippocampus on the coronal MRI ( Fig 1 C), and subdural occipital bleeding on both sides, but no tonsillar herniation ( Fig 1 D).
In view of the respiratory problems and the bilateral choanal atresia, patient 1 was intubated pending a decision regarding tracheostomy.

On the basis of the computed tomographic findings at the choanal region, it became clear that surgical correction of the choanal atresia was not an option because the stenosis of the anterior part of the nasopharynx hindered the air entry in the nose, and the narrow nasopharynx left no room laterally, vertically, or sagittally at the level of the choana.
Despite intensive care, patient 1 died at the age of 25 days.
Postmortem DNA analysis revealed a de novo Tyr375Cys mutation in the FGFR2 gene.
